subject: Re: [Read_Alphabet] QS-SAMPA: a proposed format for plain-text Quickscript
msgSnippet: Thanks for all your effort, Paul. It looks great. Aside from the alternate letters, the only thing I noticed is that the name dot is still mapped to / .
messageBody:
Thanks for all your effort, Paul. It looks great. Aside from the
alternate letters, the only thing I noticed is that the name dot is
still mapped to '/'. Personally I'd like to be able to type '/' in QS,
which is one of the reasons I proposed moving the name dot to the
backquote key. Also, are you planning to add angle brackets?

For typing in email, I had in mind following QS-SAMPA, so "bird" would
be /byrd/. If your font becomes the de-facto standard for ligatures,
then of course /bPd/ would work as well, but that's an extension of
QS-SAMPA that is very un-SAMPA-like. If someone sends me QS in
plain-text, I wouldn't expect it to look as beautiful as a finished
document with specified font size, etc. So if letters that could be in
ligatures remain unconnected, that seems fine to me.

Regarding the alternate letters 'Noon' and 'Up', I don't think it will
be difficult to implement their use in software. All you have to do is
substitute 'q' for 'n' and 'V' for 'y' in certain entries in your
dictionary. This is what I had in mind:
http://staff.washington.edu/freeman/qs/noon_up.pdf

If anyone has corrections and/or additions to the lists of letters I
have in that document, please let me know.

I'll bet if you reread pp 14-15 in the QM and try to follow the
recommendations while writing by hand, you'll find that this becomes
natural right away. It's much easier than other aspects of Senior QS.

Ted

> Open type font, and not all applications support this type of substitution.
>
> I used your letters for my ligatures. I would have liked to have the
> font automatically generate ligature, but this too may be too hard to
> do. I followed the instructions for fontforge, and then noticed at the
> bottom of the page for these instructions that many applications won't
> read ligature tables. Office, for example, won't. I did a quick search
> on line, and it seems that True Type does not even support ligatures.
> But John Cowan said the opposite, that it was more common for
> applications to read the ligature table than the kerning table, so what
> is going on here?
>
> That brings up another slight problem, what to do with /3r/. In SAMPA,
> /3r/ is of course expressed as /3r/, but right now in ThothSampa it is
> represented as P. So if we are writing bird in an email, do we write

> /b3rd/
>
> or
>
> /bPd/
>
> or
>
> /byrd/
>
> ?
